item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Flowcharts
item.description:
Personal research subjects

Flowcharts

Flowcharts are used extensively in almost all medical research.

Figure 1. Examples of flowcharts in medical research. Circo layout.

Why program a figure?

Upsides

  • Figures generated and updated inside your program
  • Vector based
  • Open-source
  • Reproducibility
  • Copy paste

Downsides

  • Steeper learning curve than “point-and-click”
  • Time-consuming for special circumstances

Using the DiagrammeR package

Syntax

Based on DOT programming language and graphViz engine for rendering. Almost 30 years old, but still updated. DiagrammeR package allows DOT programming and graphViz rendering inside R environment.

Central to using the DiagrammeR package in R is the grViz() statement. This function expects 3 statements:
1. graph statement (optional)
2. node statement
3. edge statement

Simple example

#install.packages("DiagrammeR")
library(DiagrammeR)

grViz("
      digraph{
      
      # graph statement
      graph [layout = dot]
      
      #node statement
      node [shape = box, fixedsize=true, style=filled, fillcolor=honeydew, fontname=helvetica]
      A; B; C; D; E; F; G
      
      #edge statement
      A->{B C D E F G}
      }
")

Figure 2. Simple example. DOT layout.

Layout

For now, focus on two types 1. dot (hierarchical)
2. circo (circular) More exist

Integration with existing prgoramming

In R integration is done using footnotes and @@ operator.

Example

a <- LETTERS

grViz(diagram = "
      digraph{
      
      # graph statement
      graph [layout=circo]
      
      # node statements
      node[shape=circle, style=filled, fillcolor=honeydew]
      A [label = '@@1-1']
      B [label = '@@1-2']
      C [label = '@@1-3']
      D [label = '@@1-4']
      E [label = '@@1-5']
      F [label = '@@1-6']
      G [label = '@@1-7']
      
      node[shape=box, style=filled, fillcolor=lightblue]
      H [label = '@@1-8']
      I [label = '@@1-9']
      J [label = '@@1-10']
      K [label = '@@1-11']
      L [label = '@@1-12']
      M [label = '@@1-13']
      N [label = '@@1-14']

      # edge statements
      {A B C}->{H I J K N} 
      G->{L M N}

      }
      [1]: LETTERS[1:14]
      ")

Flowchart example

# Body of nodes in flowchart. \n indicates new line
set.seed(1)
cohort <- data.frame("pnr"=1:1000, "pre_cancer"=rbinom(1000, 1, 0.01), "emigration"=rbinom(1000, 1, 0.01), "group"=rbinom(1000, 3, 0.3))

flow <- data.frame("tekst"=c("Patients between 1995-2020",
                              "Exluded due to previous cancer\n",
                              "Exluded due to emigration\n",
                              "Total exluded",
                              "Total included in study",
                              "Group 0",
                              "Group 1",
                              "Group 2",
                              "Group 3"))

flow$n[1] <- nrow(cohort)
flow$n[2] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$pre_cancer==1,])
flow$n[3] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$emigration==1,])
flow$n[4] <- flow$n[2] + flow$n[3]
cohort <- cohort[cohort$pre_cancer==0 & cohort$emigration==0,]
flow$n[5] <- nrow(cohort)
flow$n[6] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==0,])
flow$n[7] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==1,])
flow$n[8] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==2,])
flow$n[9] <- nrow(cohort[cohort$group==3,])


# Putting n and text in one cell with correct formating and alignment

flow$ntekst <- with(flow, paste0("n = ", format(n, big.mark=",", trim=TRUE), " ",tekst))

# Putting exclusion into one cell
exclusions <- with(flow, paste0(ntekst[2], ntekst[3], ntekst[4]))

# Removing exclusions from flow data.frame
flow <- flow[c(1,5:9),]

flowchart <- grViz(diagram="
      digraph{
      graph[layout=dot, fontsize=12]
      
      #body text for all except exclusions
      node [shape=box, fixedsize=false, fontname=helvetica]
      A [label = '@@1-1']
      B [label = '@@1-2']
      G0 [label = '@@1-3']
      G1 [label = '@@1-4']
      G2 [label = '@@1-5']
      G3 [label = '@@1-6']

      #body text for exlusions
      node [shape=box, fixedsize=false, fontname=helvetica]
      Excl [label = '@@2']

      #Empty cells for invisible points
      node [style=invis, width=0, height=0]
      P1 [label ='']
      P2 [label ='']

      #edge statements in up/down direction
      A->P1 [arrowhead = none]
      P1->Excl
      P1->B
      B->P2 [arrowhead = none]
      P2->{G0 G1 G2 G3}
      
      #edge statement for vertical edge to exclusions
      subgraph{
      rank=same; P1; Excl;
      }
      }
      
      [1]: flow$ntekst[1:6]
      [2]: exclusions
      ")
flowchart

Figure 3. Example flow chart. Dot layout.

Exporting

library(htmltools)
library(DiagrammeRsvg)
library(rsvg)

#Personal preferred export types: svg  for vector based, png for picture based graphics. Each file type has pros and cons. Don't mind warning message <unknown>:1753848: Invalid asm.js: Function definition doesn't match use

# svg
flowchart %>%
    export_svg %>% charToRaw %>% rsvg_svg("graph.svg")

# png 
flowchart %>%
    export_svg %>% charToRaw %>% rsvg_png("graph.png")

# pdf
flowchart %>%
    export_svg %>% charToRaw %>% rsvg_pdf("graph.pdf")

# html
save_html(HTML(export_svg(flowchart)), file = "graph.html")

Extended reading

https://rich-iannone.github.io/DiagrammeR/graphviz_and_mermaid.html
https://graphviz.org
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/DiagrammeR/index.html

item.title: AIM
item.description:
The aim of this site is to

  • provide up-to-date scientifically based information in the specialty of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, within our expert fields.
  • offer access to scientific information in a form readable for also non-doctors
  • express our opinion on actual issues – called “editorials”
  • give access to presentations made by our staff

The information is indexed according to the index below

Scope

The access to rapid and often free information within any field has expanded rapidly by time. During the latest decade, however, in many areas, ideological issues increasingly influence the selection of information presented, with the consequence that even professionals sometimes apparently live in “different worlds”.
We all know that nobody can be 100% objective. Our way strive for objectivity is based on three principles: No commercials on this site. None of us are engaged in boards of pharmaceutical companies, and none of us have shares in industry. This is of course no guaranty of objectivity, like people who have such engagements may be fully objective. But nevertheless. We also attempt to go beyond apparently conflicting results in different studies on the same topic, and to do better than just to declare: We can draw no conclusion, as different studies emerge with different results. Our experience tell us, at usually, one might explain the apparently different results. Good studies generally provide more reliable results than poor studies.
In order to make the information on this site relevant for clinically working people, all who are presenting information on this site are clinically working colleagues (part-time or fulltime). Finally, we encourage colleagues who want to share useful information and at the same time fulfill our principles outlined, to send us such information. We have full right to refuse such an upload, but will be happy to do so, if we find the information useful.
So, please enjoy.

INDEX

The information is indexed according to the following headlines:

  • Short- and long-term health issues with use of hormonal contraception
    • Use of hormonal contraception in Denmark / Scandinavia
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of venous thrombosis
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of arterial thrombosis
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of breast cancer risk
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of ovarian cancer
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of endometrial cancer
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of colo-rectal cancer
    • Hormonal contraception and risk of depression/suicides
    • Hormonal contraception; clinical notes
    • Frequent questions and our answers
  • Hormone therapy and cancer risk
    • How does different types of hormones influence the risk of different female cancers
  • Miscarriages
    • The frequency of miscarriages in Denmark through 40 years.
    • Reproductive prognosis after pregnancy losses
    • Associations between miscarriages and future health in mothers
    • Frequent question and our answers
  • Induced abortion
    • Medically and surgically induced abortion in Denmark 2000-2019
    • Early pregnancy national quality assessment in Denmark (Tigrab.dk)
    • 1st trimester medically induced abortion
    • 2nd trimester medically induced abortion
    • Frequent question and our answers
  • Post-term birth-induction and stillbirth risk

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: An example journal article
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
